His work on the electromagnetic relay laid the foundation for the telegraph, and the SI unit of inductance is named after him.

mainEvents.description: Appointed as the first Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1877 seems to capture the moment when Joseph Henry, a pioneer of electromagnetism, was at the pinnacle of his career, having served as the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution for over three decades, overseeing the institution's growth and advancement. He had already made significant contributions to science and was respected for his brilliance and leadership.
title: Joseph Henry
name: Joseph Henry

description: John Randolph is a prominent Virginian political figure known for his fiery speeches, staunch defense of traditional Southern values, and fierce opposition to the federal government's increasing power.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1811 seems to capture the moment when John Randolph, a powerful voice in the House of Representatives, was at the height of his influence, before the Missouri Compromise and his break with the Democratic-Republican Party.
title: John Randolph
name: John Randolph

description: Richard Henry Lee is a prominent Founding Father and statesman from Virginia, known for advocating colonial independence and drafting the Lee Resolution, which led to the Declaration of Independence. He was a delegate to the Continental Congress, served as the sixth president of the Confederation Congress, and was a U.S. Senator from Virginia.

mainEvents.description: Richard Henry Lee proposed the Lee Resolution.
Richard Henry Lee served as the president of the Continental Congress.
Richard Henry Lee was a United States Senator from Virginia.

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1795-1805 seems to capture the moment when Richard Henry Lee was in his later years, reflecting on his significant contributions to the founding of the nation and his continued service as a U.S. Senator. It was a time when he was still actively involved in public life but perhaps also aware of his declining health and the approaching end of his long career.
title: Richard Henry Lee
name: Richard Henry Lee

description: William Tecumseh Sherman is a Union general renowned for his strategic brilliance and controversial scorched-earth tactics during the American Civil War, most notably his 'March to the Sea' through Georgia.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1866 seems to capture the moment when Sherman, having achieved his most famous military success, was beginning to emerge from the emotional turmoil of war and to forge a new path for himself as a public figure.
title: William T. Sherman
name: William Tecumseh Sherman

description: Edwin McMasters Stanton is a prominent lawyer and politician who served as the United States Secretary of War during the Civil War, a key figure in the Union's victory.  He is known for his strong will and commitment to the abolition of slavery. He later clashed with President Andrew Johnson over Reconstruction, which led to Johnson's impeachment by the House of Representatives.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1872 seems to capture the moment when Edwin McMasters Stanton, a powerful figure in the tumultuous years of the Civil War and Reconstruction,  has weathered the storms of those times and stands on the precipice of a new chapter, nominated to the Supreme Court but facing ill health that will cut his life short.
title: Edwin McMasters Stanton
name: Edwin McMasters Stanton

description: Benjamin Helm Bristow is a prominent American lawyer and politician who served as the 30th United States Secretary of the Treasury and the first Solicitor General, known for breaking up the corrupt Whiskey Ring and advocating for civil rights.

mainEvents.description: Appointed U.S. Secretary of the Treasury

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1874 seems to capture the moment when Bristow, a rising Republican reformer, was appointed Secretary of the Treasury, and was poised to use his office to dismantle the corrupt Whiskey Ring.
title: Gen. Benjamin Helm Bristow
name: Benjamin Helm Bristow

description: George Brinton McClellan is a Union Army general known for his organizational skills, cautiousness, and ultimately unsuccessful campaigns against Robert E. Lee, including the Peninsula Campaign and Antietam. He later served as governor of New Jersey and was the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for president in 1864.

mainEvents.description: Commanding General of the US Army
Lost command of the Army of the Potomac

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1888 seems to capture the moment when McClellan, removed from military command and facing a political future, reflects on his controversial wartime career and prepares for his final years as a public figure and author.
title: George Brinton McClellan
name: George Brinton McClellan

description: Zachary Taylor is a significant American military figure who rose to the rank of Major General, earning the nickname "Old Rough and Ready" for his victories in the Mexican-American War.  His victories propelled him to the Presidency despite his political inexperience,  but he died after 16 months in office, leaving his legacy to the 'Compromise of 1850.'
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1850-52 seems to capture the moment when Taylor, having secured the presidency, stands at the precipice of his administration. It is a time of transition, marked by the end of his illustrious military career, and the beginning of his turbulent presidency, burdened by the brewing sectional crisis over slavery.
title: Zachary Taylor
name: Zachary Taylor

description: Horatio Gates is a controversial figure in American history, known for his victory at Saratoga, which helped secure French support for the Continental Army, but also for his disastrous defeat at Camden.

mainEvents.description: Became Adjutant General of the Continental Army

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1782 seems to capture the moment when Horatio Gates, having just achieved victory at Saratoga, was at the height of his military career, yet on the cusp of his downfall at Camden, foreshadowing a turbulent future.
title: Horatio Gates
name: Horatio Gates

description: Henry George is a renowned American political economist and journalist who gained global recognition for his revolutionary economic philosophy, Georgism, advocating for a single tax on land values to create a more equitable and productive society.

mainEvents.description: Ran for Mayor of New York City

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1888 seems to capture the moment when Henry George, a rising star in American political economy, was poised to further his career in the public arena, having published his groundbreaking 'Progress and Poverty' and 'Protection or Free Trade', and just after a close run for the Mayor of New York City.
title: Henry George
name: Henry George

description: Bessie Potter Vonnoh is a notable American sculptor recognized for her small bronzes, mainly depicting domestic scenes, and her garden fountains. She was a pioneer in miniature sculpture and aimed to portray 'the joy and swing of modern American life' through her works.

mainEvents.description: Studied at Art Institute of Chicago
Awarded Bronze Medal at Exposition Universelle

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1895 seems to capture the moment when Bessie Potter Vonnoh was emerging as a prominent sculptor, having already gained recognition for her works at the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition and having traveled to Europe to study with renowned artists like Auguste Rodin. This period marked the start of her prolific career, characterized by small-scale bronzes that captured the everyday life of Americans.
title: Bessie Potter Vonnoh
name: Bessie Potter Vonnoh

description: John Witherspoon is a Scottish-American Presbyterian minister, educator, farmer, slaveholder, and Founding Father, known for his role in the American Revolution and presidency of the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University). He was a signatory to the Declaration of Independence and helped shape the Presbyterian Church in America.

mainEvents.description: Became President of the College of New Jersey

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1794 seems to capture the moment when John Witherspoon, nearing the end of his life, reflects upon his long and impactful career, having served as president of the College of New Jersey for over two decades and leaving a lasting mark on the development of the United States' national character.
title: John Witherspoon
name: John Witherspoon

description: Cornelius Vanderbilt is a 19th-century American business tycoon who built his wealth in railroads and shipping. He was nicknamed "The Commodore" and became one of the richest Americans in history. Vanderbilt's shrewd business practices and investments in infrastructure dramatically impacted the growth of the United States.

mainEvents.description: Start of the California Gold Rush
Start of the American Civil War
Creation of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1846 seems to capture the moment when Vanderbilt was at the peak of his steamboat empire, having just taken control of the Stonington Railroad and building towards his later dominance in the railroad industry.
title: Cornelius Vanderbilt
name: Cornelius Vanderbilt

description: John Muir is a Scottish-born American naturalist, writer, and environmental philosopher, best known for his advocacy for wilderness preservation. He co-founded the Sierra Club and helped establish Yosemite National Park.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1917 from a 1909 photograph seems to capture the moment when John Muir, nearing the end of his long and influential life, had already established his legacy as a passionate advocate for wilderness preservation.
title: John Muir
name: John Muir

description: Alexander Hamilton is a Founding Father, statesman, and the first U.S. Secretary of the Treasury, known for his financial policies, contributions to the Federalist Papers, and tragic duel with Aaron Burr.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1806 seems to capture the moment when Alexander Hamilton, a man of immense intellect and ambition, is approaching the twilight of his political career, facing a future clouded by partisan conflict and a fatal duel.
title: Alexander Hamilton
name: Alexander Hamilton

description: Charles Evans Hughes is a prominent American jurist and statesman known for serving as Chief Justice of the United States, Secretary of State, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, and Governor of New York. He was a Republican who narrowly lost the 1916 presidential election to Woodrow Wilson.

mainEvents.description: Born in Glens Falls, New York
Lost Presidential Election to Woodrow Wilson

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1921 seems to capture the moment when Charles Evans Hughes was at the peak of his political career, having just served as Secretary of State under Presidents Harding and Coolidge and having successfully negotiated the Washington Naval Treaty, a significant accomplishment in international diplomacy.
title: Charles Evans Hughes
name: Charles Evans Hughes

description: Pauline Morton Sabin is a prominent American activist and Republican party official known for leading the movement to repeal the 18th Amendment (Prohibition). She founded the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform (WONPR) and used her social status and charismatic personality to influence public opinion and gain support for repeal.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1926 seems to capture the moment when Pauline Morton Sabin, a rising political figure and socialite, was starting to voice her opposition to Prohibition. The portrait reflects her elegance and social status, which would be crucial in her later efforts to mobilize women and shape public opinion.
title: Pauline Morton Sabin
name: Pauline Morton Sabin

description: Juliette Gordon Low is a pioneering figure in the Girl Scout movement, renowned for her dedication to empowering girls through education, outdoor skills, and civic engagement. She founded the Girl Scouts of the USA in 1912, inspiring millions of girls across generations.

mainEvents.description: Became first president of Girl Scouts

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1887 seems to capture the moment when Juliette Gordon Low, newly married and in the midst of her social life, was about to embark on a journey that would redefine her life - her journey to empower girls through the Girl Scouts.
title: Juliette Gordon Low
name: Juliette Gordon Low

description: Frida Kahlo is a Mexican painter known for her powerful self-portraits and surrealist style, which often explored themes of identity, pain, and Mexican culture. Her work is highly celebrated for its vibrant colors, symbolic imagery, and autobiographical elements.

mainEvents.description: First solo exhibition in New York

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1933 seems to capture the moment when Frida Kahlo, a young artist navigating the complexities of her marriage to Diego Rivera and her recovery from a debilitating bus accident, was finding her voice and exploring her artistic style, drawing inspiration from Mexican folk art and her own personal experiences.
title: Frida Kahlo
name: Frida Kahlo

description: Andrew Johnson is a controversial figure in American history, serving as the 17th president following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln. He is known for his Reconstruction policies, which favored a rapid restoration of Southern states to the Union without significant protections for newly freed slaves. This resulted in conflict with Congress and led to his impeachment, though he was acquitted by a single vote.

mainEvents.description: Impeached by the House of Representatives

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in after 1866 seems to capture the moment when Andrew Johnson, embittered by his impeachment and political battles, reflects on his turbulent presidency, a period marked by both achievements and failures, shaping his lasting legacy.
title: Andrew Johnson
name: Andrew Johnson

description: Benjamin Lay is a renowned English-born Quaker activist who dedicated his life to fighting slavery. He was a prolific writer and a passionate advocate for the abolition of slavery, famously disrupting Quaker meetings with provocative demonstrations. His radical beliefs challenged societal norms and inspired future generations of abolitionists.

mainEvents.description: Moved to Barbados as a merchant
Published 'All Slave-Keepers That Keep the Innocent in Bondage: Apostates'

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1750-58 seems to capture the moment when Benjamin Lay, having established himself as a leading abolitionist in Pennsylvania, was a formidable force in the fight against slavery, even though his radical methods made him unpopular with many Quakers.
title: Benjamin Lay
name: Benjamin Lay

description: Daniel Boone is a legendary American frontiersman known for his exploration and settlement of Kentucky, founding Boonesborough, and blazing the Wilderness Road.

mainEvents.description: Boone fought in the Battle of Blue Licks

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1820 seems to capture the moment when Daniel Boone, having faced many hardships and triumphs in his pioneering days, was nearing the end of his life, but still maintaining the rugged spirit of his adventurous youth.
title: Daniel Boone
name: Daniel Boone

description: John Brooks Henderson is a prominent figure in American history, best known for co-authoring the Thirteenth Amendment and serving as a United States Senator representing Missouri. His legacy is marked by significant contributions to the fight against slavery and his involvement in important political and legal events during his lifetime.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1895 seems to capture the moment when John Brooks Henderson, a veteran of the political arena, reflects on a life filled with significant contributions to the nation, including his pivotal role in the abolishment of slavery.
title: John Brooks Henderson
name: John Brooks Henderson

description: Belva Ann Bennett Lockwood is a pioneering American lawyer, politician, educator, and author who was a champion of women's rights and suffrage. She broke barriers as the first woman to practice law before the U.S. Supreme Court and ran for president twice, becoming the first woman to appear on official ballots.

mainEvents.description: Admitted to practice law before the U.S. Supreme Court
Ran for president on the National Equal Rights Party ticket
Ran for president again on the National Equal Rights Party ticket

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1913 seems to capture the moment when Belva Ann Bennett Lockwood, after overcoming decades of social and legal barriers, stood firmly as a prominent figure in the women's rights movement, her career as a lawyer and advocate reaching new heights.
title: Belva Ann Lockwood
name: Belva Ann Bennett Lockwood

description: Anne Catharine Hoof Green is a pioneering American printer and publisher who took over her husband's Maryland Gazette after his death, becoming one of the first women publishers in the colonies. She successfully led the business and gained recognition for her accomplishments in a male-dominated field.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1769 seems to capture the moment when Anne Catharine Hoof Green was navigating the challenges of running a printing business after her husband's death, showcasing her strength and resilience as a businesswoman and a pioneering female publisher in the American colonies.
title: Anne Catharine Hoof Green
name: Anne Catharine Hoof Green

description: Lillian D. Wald is a pioneering American nurse and social activist, best known for founding the Henry Street Settlement in New York City, a vital resource for impoverished families. She championed public health nursing, advocating for the rights of women, minorities, and children, even joining the NAACP.

mainEvents.description: Became a founding member of the NAACP

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1919 seems to capture the moment when Lillian D. Wald, already a respected figure in public health, was transitioning to a leading voice in the fight for social justice,  with her work on issues like child labor and racial equality.
title: Lillian D. Wald
name: Lillian D. Wald

description: Abraham Lincoln is a self-educated lawyer who rose from poverty to become a U.S. Representative and Senator, before leading the nation through the Civil War, abolishing slavery, and unifying the nation.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1860 seems to capture the moment when Lincoln was just beginning to reach national prominence, having won the Republican nomination but facing the daunting challenge of the looming Civil War and the South's secession.
title: Abraham Lincoln
name: Abraham Lincoln

description: Zachary Taylor is a military hero who rose to the presidency after his victories in the Mexican-American War. He was known for his straight-forward nature and was nicknamed "Old Rough and Ready". Taylor died just 16 months into his term of office.

mainEvents.description: Zachary Taylor was born in Barboursville, Virginia
Taylor served in the War of 1812
Taylor commanded troops in the Black Hawk War
Taylor led American forces in the Mexican-American War
Zachary Taylor died in Washington D.C.

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1848 seems to capture the moment when Zachary Taylor was on the cusp of political fame. Having secured victory after victory in the Mexican-American War, he was a beloved national hero but had not yet entered the political arena. The portrait shows a man on the verge of a new chapter in his life, a time of great promise and uncertainty.
title: Zachary Taylor
name: Zachary Taylor

description: Stephen Arnold Douglas is a prominent figure in American history, known for his advocacy of popular sovereignty and his pivotal role in the 1860 presidential election. He served as a U.S. Senator, House Representative, and Supreme Court Justice. He was a key figure in the Compromise of 1850, which sought to avert a sectional crisis, and the Kansas-Nebraska Act, which further inflamed tensions over slavery.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1860 seems to capture the moment when Stephen Douglas, a political titan, faces the weight of the coming Civil War.  The 1860 presidential election, which he lost to Abraham Lincoln, marked the culmination of his career, and his legacy was forever intertwined with the debate over slavery that led to the nation's greatest crisis.
title: Stephen Arnold Douglas
name: Stephen Arnold Douglas

description: John Charles Frémont is a controversial figure known for his explorations of the American West, his involvement in the Mexican-American War, and his role as the first Republican presidential candidate.

mainEvents.description: Led the Bear Flag Revolt in California
Served as Governor of Arizona Territory

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in the 1850s seems to capture the moment when Frémont, a seasoned explorer and military leader, is transitioning into a prominent political figure, navigating the turbulent waters of the pre-Civil War era, perhaps contemplating his upcoming presidential candidacy.
title: John Charles Frémont
name: John Charles Frémont

description: Chester Alan Arthur is a Republican lawyer from New York who briefly served as the 20th vice president under President James A. Garfield and became the 21st president after Garfield's death.

mainEvents.description: Appointed as Collector of the Port of New York
Assumed the presidency after Garfield's death
Signed the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in April 1884 seems to capture the moment when Chester Alan Arthur is still in the early stages of his presidency, having only assumed the office a few months before after the assassination of President Garfield.
title: Chester Alan Arthur
name: Chester Alan Arthur

description: Lucretia Coffin Mott is a prominent American Quaker abolitionist, women's rights activist, and social reformer. She is best known for her work at the Seneca Falls Convention and for her staunch commitment to equality and justice, advocating for both women's rights and the end of slavery.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1842 seems to capture the moment when Lucretia Coffin Mott, already a renowned Quaker minister and abolitionist, is on the verge of her landmark involvement in the women's rights movement, as her participation in the World Anti-Slavery Convention the previous year had ignited her passion for advocating for gender equality.
title: Lucretia Coffin Mott
name: Lucretia Coffin Mott

description: Thomas Hart Benton is a prominent American politician, attorney, soldier, and senator who advocated for westward expansion and opposed the expansion of slavery. He was known as 'Old Bullion' for his strong stance on hard money policies.

mainEvents.description: Elected to the U.S. Senate from Missouri

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1861 seems to capture the moment when Benton was a seasoned statesman, having served as senator for three decades and witnessing the tumultuous debate on slavery tearing the nation apart. Despite the loss of his Senate seat, Benton remained a staunch advocate for the Union, clinging to his Democratic ideals even as the party fractured over the slavery issue. He was 79 years old, a figure of both experience and defiance, facing a future shrouded in the uncertainty of the Civil War.
title: Thomas Hart Benton
name: Thomas Hart Benton

description: John Tyler is a complex figure who served as the tenth president of the United States, succeeding William Henry Harrison after his death. While supporting states' rights, Tyler vetoed many Whig bills and was expelled from the party. He is known for annexing Texas and the Webster-Ashburton Treaty, which peacefully settled the Maine-Canada border.

mainEvents.description: Born in Charles City County, Virginia

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1859 seems to capture the moment when John Tyler, a former president and now a Confederate statesman, reflects on his tumultuous career and the looming civil war that would forever divide the nation he once led.
title: John Tyler
name: John Tyler

description: Isaac Mayer Wise is a prominent American Reform rabbi, editor, and author who played a pivotal role in shaping American Judaism, particularly the Reform movement.  He founded Hebrew Union College, the first rabbinical seminary in the United States, and was instrumental in the formation of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. He was also a prolific writer, known for his books on Jewish history, theology, and philosophy, as well as his novels.

mainEvents.description: Established Central Conference of American Rabbis

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1881 seems to capture the moment when Isaac Mayer Wise, a seasoned leader of the Reform movement, stood at the cusp of his legacy. He had already established the Hebrew Union College and the Central Conference of American Rabbis, and was deeply invested in uniting American Jews, while also engaging in theological debates and advocating for Jewish rights. This portrait reflects the weight of his accomplishments and the anticipation of his enduring impact on American Judaism.
title: Isaac Mayer Wise
name: Isaac Mayer Wise

description: Margaret Fuller is a prominent American writer, critic, and women's rights advocate known for her pioneering feminist work, "Woman in the Nineteenth Century", and her groundbreaking role as the first female war correspondent in American journalism.

mainEvents.description: Fuller published "Woman in the Nineteenth Century".
Fuller became the first female war correspondent in the United States.

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1848 seems to capture the moment when Margaret Fuller, at the pinnacle of her career, was deeply engaged in European affairs and the Italian revolutions, a period that would define her legacy as a bold and insightful feminist and intellectual.
title: Margaret Fuller
name: Margaret Fuller

description: William Lloyd Garrison is a prominent American abolitionist and journalist, best known for his anti-slavery newspaper "The Liberator" and his fierce advocacy for immediate emancipation.

mainEvents.description: Burned a copy of the Constitution

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1833 seems to capture the moment when William Lloyd Garrison, a young and fiery abolitionist, is on the verge of establishing himself as a leading voice in the movement. He had already founded "The Liberator" and was building a national platform for his radical views, challenging the deeply entrenched institution of slavery in the United States.
title: William Lloyd Garrison
name: William Lloyd Garrison

description: Noah Webster is a prominent American lexicographer, educator, and reformer who revolutionized English language education in the United States. His  'Blue-Backed Speller' taught generations of American children how to spell and read, and his dictionary standardized American English, becoming a foundation for modern American lexicography.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1833 seems to capture the moment when Noah Webster, at the age of 75, is at the height of his career as a lexicographer,  having just completed his monumental 'American Dictionary of the English Language', a  monument to American nationalism and a testament to his tireless dedication to improving American education.
title: Noah Webster
name: Noah Webster

description: George Washington is a Founding Father, the first president of the United States, and is widely considered the "Father of His Country." He led the Continental Army to victory in the American Revolutionary War and oversaw the adoption of the U.S. Constitution.

mainEvents.description: Appointed Commander in Chief of the Continental Army.
Elected as the first President of the United States.

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1796 seems to capture the moment when George Washington, at the height of his political career, was preparing to step down from the presidency and return to his beloved Mount Vernon, reflecting on the successes and challenges of building a new nation.
title: George Washington (Lansdowne Portrait)
name: George Washington

description: David Rittenhouse is a renowned American astronomer, inventor, and public official who made significant contributions to the development of science and the United States. He was the first director of the United States Mint and a prominent member of the American Philosophical Society.

mainEvents.description: Became first director of the United States Mint

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1796 seems to capture the moment when David Rittenhouse, at the age of 64, stood at the pinnacle of his scientific career. Having already made groundbreaking contributions to astronomy and surveying, he was then leading the newly established United States Mint, a testament to his multifaceted brilliance and service to his nation.
title: David Rittenhouse
name: David Rittenhouse

description: Abraham Lincoln is a renowned American president who steered the nation through its most turbulent period, the Civil War. He abolished slavery, strengthened the federal government, and preserved the Union. He is also known for his eloquent speeches, including the Gettysburg Address.

mainEvents.description: The start of the Civil War

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1861 seems to capture the moment when Abraham Lincoln, having just assumed the presidency amidst a burgeoning national crisis, grapples with the weight of the Union's future and the specter of civil war. His gaze, etched with resolve, reflects the challenges he faced in uniting a nation divided by slavery.
title: Abraham Lincoln
name: Abraham Lincoln

description: James Madison is a Founding Father, the fourth President of the United States, and is known for his significant contributions to drafting and promoting the Constitution.  He is also known as the 'Father of the Constitution'.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1829-30 seems to capture the moment when James Madison was reflecting on his life's accomplishments, his presidency coming to a close in 1817, and the challenging War of 1812 having just ended.
title: James Madison
name: James Madison

description: Ulysses Simpson Grant is a celebrated American military leader and politician who served as the 18th president of the United States. He is best known for his decisive victories during the Civil War, leading the Union to victory over the Confederacy, and for his efforts to oversee Reconstruction and protect African Americans' rights.

mainEvents.description: Surrendered Robert E. Lee at Appomattox

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1880 seems to capture the moment when Ulysses Simpson Grant, still a young man in his late fifties, had achieved the pinnacle of his military career and was navigating the tumultuous political landscape as a popular yet controversial figure. He was a seasoned leader, having guided the Union to victory in the Civil War, and was now facing the challenge of rebuilding the nation and securing the rights of freed slaves,  a task that would continue to shape the future of the United States.
title: Ulysses S. Grant
name: Ulysses Simpson Grant

description: William Henry Harrison is a prominent figure in American history, serving as the ninth president of the United States and the first to die in office. He was also a decorated military leader, known for his victories in the Northwest Indian War and the War of 1812. He was instrumental in opening the western territories for settlement and is remembered for his innovative campaigning tactics.

mainEvents.description: Born in Charles City County, Virginia

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1813 seems to capture the moment when William Henry Harrison,  having risen to prominence in the Indiana Territory, was about to embark on his military leadership in the War of 1812, following the Battle of Tippecanoe and his victories over Tecumseh’s confederation.
title: William Henry Harrison
name: William Henry Harrison

description: John Quincy Adams is a prominent figure in American history, serving as the sixth president and eighth secretary of state. He was a skilled diplomat, known for his negotiation of the Adams-Onís Treaty, which acquired Florida for the United States.  A staunch advocate for abolition, Adams championed the rights of minorities, including women and Native Americans.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1844 seems to capture the moment when John Quincy Adams, after a turbulent presidency and a loss of public support, was reinvigorated by his return to Congress, where he would serve with distinction for nearly two decades as a champion of abolition and the rights of minorities.
title: John Quincy Adams
name: John Quincy Adams

description: John Jordan Crittenden is a prominent American statesman and politician from Kentucky, known for his long and varied career in politics, law, and diplomacy, often serving as a compromiser in tumultuous times.

mainEvents.description: Crittenden becomes the 17th Governor of Kentucky
Crittenden becomes U.S. Attorney General again

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1857 seems to capture the moment when John Jordan Crittenden, already a seasoned statesman and nearing the end of his career, is on the cusp of the Civil War, facing the challenge of his life: to save the Union through compromise.
title: John Jordan Crittenden
name: John Jordan Crittenden

description: Salmon Portland Chase is a prominent American politician and jurist who served as the sixth chief justice of the United States, the 23rd governor of Ohio, and the 25th U.S. Secretary of the Treasury. He is notable for serving at the highest levels of all three branches of the federal government.

mainEvents.description: Served as Secretary of the Treasury

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1864-73 seems to capture the moment when Chase, after years of political maneuvering, ascended to the highest judicial office in the land, while simultaneously grappling with the aftermath of the Civil War and its implications for the future of the nation.
title: Salmon P. Chase
name: Salmon Portland Chase

description: Carl Schurz is a German-born American statesman, journalist, and reformer. He was a leader in the German Revolution of 1848, served as a Union general in the Civil War, and was a U.S. Senator and Secretary of the Interior. Schurz was a lifelong advocate for civil service reform, human rights, and anti-imperialism.

mainEvents.description: Fled to the U.S. after the 1848 Revolution
Served as a Union General in the Civil War

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1899 seems to capture the moment when Carl Schurz, a veteran of the Civil War and a respected statesman, was nearing the end of his long and distinguished career, reflecting on his accomplishments and the challenges facing the nation.
title: Carl Schurz
name: Carl Schurz

description: Julia Ward Howe is a prominent American author and poet, renowned for her authorship of the 'Battle Hymn of the Republic,' a pivotal song of the Union during the Civil War, and for her passionate advocacy for women's suffrage and pacifism.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in begun c. 1910; completed c. 1925 seems to capture the moment when Julia Ward Howe, a woman of great intellect and passion, had become a leading voice for social justice, having achieved international fame through her literary and political achievements.
title: Julia Ward Howe
name: Julia Ward Howe

description: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow is a renowned American poet and educator, best known for his accessible, melodious works such as "Paul Revere's Ride" and "The Song of Hiawatha." He was the first American to translate Dante's *Divine Comedy* and was one of the "fireside poets" of New England.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1869 seems to capture the moment when Longfellow, having achieved great literary success and weathered personal tragedies, is at the peak of his influence and renown. He has already lost both wives, but he continues to produce works of lasting impact. He is now a respected scholar, a revered figure in American culture.
title: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
name: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

description: Franklin Pierce is a controversial figure, the 14th US President, known for his role in the Kansas-Nebraska Act and the expansion of slavery, although he is often ranked among the worst presidents.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1853 seems to capture the moment when Franklin Pierce, having reached the pinnacle of his political ambitions, yet already facing opposition due to his support of the Kansas-Nebraska Act, must have been feeling the weight of the nation's future hanging upon him.
title: Franklin Pierce
name: Franklin Pierce

description: John Quincy Adams is a prominent historical figure who served as the sixth president of the United States, eighth secretary of state, and was the son of President John Adams. A gifted diplomat and scholar, Adams was also a key figure in the anti-slavery movement.

mainEvents.description: Elected to the House of Representatives

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1850, from an 1844 original seems to capture the moment when Adams, now in his late 70s, was a seasoned statesman, having served in both chambers of Congress, as President, and as Secretary of State. He is about to embark on a vigorous campaign to repeal the "gag rule" and promote the cause of abolition.
title: John Quincy Adams
name: John Quincy Adams

description: William Howard Taft is a prominent figure in American history, serving as both the 27th President and the 10th Chief Justice of the United States, a feat unmatched by any other individual.  He is known for his progressive policies and efforts to regulate big business. He also famously got stuck in the White House bathtub, although this story is not true.

mainEvents.description: William Howard Taft was sworn in as President.
William Howard Taft was sworn in as Chief Justice.

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1910 seems to capture the moment when William Howard Taft, recently elected as president, is poised to take on the challenges of the 20th century, embodying both the strength of his leadership and the quiet determination that defined his character.
title: William Howard Taft
name: William Howard Taft

description: Stephen Van Rensselaer III is a prominent American figure of the late 18th and early 19th centuries, known for his vast landholdings, political career, and contributions to education. As the 9th Patroon of Rensselaerswyck, he was a major landowner, a Federalist politician, and a military leader during the War of 1812.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1825-35 seems to capture the moment when Stephen Van Rensselaer III, having established his legacy as a landowner and politician, stands on the cusp of his greatest accomplishment: founding Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, a pioneering institution of higher learning.
title: Stephen Van Rensselaer III
name: Stephen Van Rensselaer III

description: Charles Cotesworth Pinckney is a prominent American Founding Father, statesman, and military officer who served as the US Minister to France and was twice nominated by the Federalist Party for President.

mainEvents.description: Born in Charles Town, South Carolina
Served as US Minister to France
Nominated for President by the Federalist Party

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1773 seems to capture the moment when Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, a young lawyer, was on the cusp of a political career. He had just married Sarah Middleton, a woman from a prominent South Carolina family, and was preparing to play an active role in the growing unrest with Great Britain.
title: Charles Cotesworth Pinckney
name: Charles Cotesworth Pinckney

description: Woodrow Wilson is a  progressive Democrat who served as the 28th president of the United States from 1913 to 1921. He championed democratic ideals and international cooperation, leading the country through World War I and advocating for the League of Nations, even though the U.S. Senate refused to join.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1919 seems to capture the moment when Woodrow Wilson, a man of both vision and conviction, is at the pinnacle of his power. Having led the United States to victory in World War I, he is poised to implement his ambitious peace plan, the Fourteen Points, and shape a new world order through the League of Nations. But the seeds of his future defeat have been sown, as the U.S. Senate remains deeply divided on the League.
title: Woodrow Wilson
name: Woodrow Wilson

description: James Monroe is a Founding Father and the fifth President of the United States, known for the Monroe Doctrine that limited European influence in the Americas, and for the Louisiana Purchase.

mainEvents.description: Elected as President of the United States

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1829 seems to capture the moment when James Monroe, retired from public life after a long and distinguished career, reflects on the legacy of his presidency, a time of national unity and expansion.
title: James Monroe
name: James Monroe

description: William McKinley is a 25th President of the United States who led the nation to victory in the Spanish-American War and oversaw the nation's economic expansion in the late 19th century.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1897 seems to capture the moment when William McKinley, a man of steady character, prepares to face the anxieties of his first term and the challenges of an increasingly powerful United States.
title: William McKinley
name: William McKinley

description: James Knox Polk is a prominent figure in American history, known for his expansionist policies as the 11th president. He orchestrated the annexation of Texas and the Oregon Territory, and acquired vast swathes of land from Mexico through the Mexican-American War, significantly shaping the modern United States.  His presidency, though short, was marked by significant achievements, but also by the growing sectional tensions that would ultimately lead to the Civil War.

mainEvents.description: Elected President of the United States
Signed the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in January-February 1846 seems to capture the moment when Polk, in the midst of his presidency, stands as a figure of both ambition and accomplishment, having already achieved the annexation of Texas and Oregon, and with the Mexican-American War ongoing.
title: James Knox Polk
name: James Knox Polk

description: Chester Alan Arthur is a Republican lawyer from New York who became the 21st president of the United States following the assassination of President James A. Garfield. He is known for his role in the patronage system, his support of civil service reform, and his efforts to modernize the U.S. Navy.

mainEvents.description: Appointed Collector of the Port of New York
Signed Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1881 seems to capture the moment when Chester Alan Arthur, a staunch supporter of the patronage system, is poised to take on the presidency, unaware of the impact his decision to sign the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act would have on American politics.
title: Chester A. Arthur
name: Chester Alan Arthur

description: Henry Cabot Lodge is a prominent American statesman, senator, and historian, known for his influential role in shaping American foreign policy during the early 20th century.

mainEvents.description: Led opposition to the Treaty of Versailles

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1890 seems to capture the moment when Henry Cabot Lodge, a rising Republican star, was in the midst of his early political career, having already served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives and the US House of Representatives, and on the cusp of his long and impactful tenure in the US Senate.
title: Henry Cabot Lodge
name: Henry Cabot Lodge

description: James Abram Garfield is a 20th President of the United States. He served in the Union Army during the American Civil War. Garfield was a Republican Congressman and a skilled orator. He was assassinated by Charles J. Guiteau in 1881.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1881 seems to capture the moment when Garfield was an up-and-coming politician, he had been elected to the Senate and the presidency,  but he had not yet made his mark on American history.  He was a young man of great promise, cut down in his prime.
title: James Garfield
name: James Abram Garfield

description: Thomas Jefferson is a Founding Father, architect, lawyer, philosopher, and the third president of the United States, known for his authorship of the Declaration of Independence and his role in promoting democracy and individual liberties.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1786 seems to capture the moment when Thomas Jefferson was serving as a Minister to France, a time when he was shaping U.S. foreign policy, experiencing personal loss with the death of his wife, and actively engaging with the ideas of the French Revolution.
title: Thomas Jefferson
name: Thomas Jefferson

description: Rutherford Birchard Hayes is a 19th-century American lawyer, soldier, and politician who served as the 19th president of the United States from 1877 to 1881. Known for his honesty and commitment to civil service reform, his presidency was marked by the end of Reconstruction and the Great Railroad Strike of 1877.

mainEvents.description: Hayes is born in Delaware, Ohio.
Hayes is elected Governor of Ohio.
Hayes wins the disputed election for the presidency.

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1881 seems to capture the moment when Rutherford B. Hayes, after a long and arduous career in both the military and the political arena, is firmly established as President of the United States, but having just ended Reconstruction and confronted by the Great Railroad Strike of 1877, facing the daunting task of navigating his administration through the challenging economic and political landscape of the late 19th century.
title: Rutherford B. Hayes
name: Rutherford Birchard Hayes

description: James Buchanan is a lawyer, politician, and the 15th President of the United States. He is known for his role in the lead up to the Civil War and his staunch advocacy for states' rights, especially regarding slavery, often siding with the South. Although personally opposed to slavery, he opposed abolitionists and minimized the role of the federal government.

mainEvents.description: Served as US Minister to Russia
Served as US Secretary of State

portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in 1859 seems to capture the moment when James Buchanan, having reached the zenith of his political career as the 15th President of the United States, navigates the turbulent waters of the sectional crisis over slavery and the looming threat of secession, a period that ultimately defined his legacy.
title: James Buchanan
name: James Buchanan

description: Theodore Roosevelt is a multifaceted historical figure who served as the 26th President of the United States, a renowned conservationist, a military leader, and a prolific author, known for his energy and charisma.
portraitMoment: This portrait drawn in c. 1908-10 seems to capture the moment when Theodore Roosevelt, now nearing the end of his second term, is at the peak of his influence,  his legacy as a conservationist and a progressive president solidified.
title: Theodore Roosevelt
name: Theodore Roosevelt
